 The fact that an institution has existed in one form for a long time is not a rational reason to prohibit change in the institution. Indeed, marriage has changed a great deal over time. Marriage partners have become equals under the law. This is good, I think. In the early years of the republic, spouses lived under the doctrine of coverture, which meant that the wife was covered by her husband legally, and her property became his property, not hers. Married women who earned wages found that their wages were the property of their husbands, not of the couple together and not of the woman who earned the wages. One of the earliest women's rights campaigns was the campaign for married women's property rights. By the end of the 19th century, states had all enacted married women's property laws, and the doctrine of coverture was effectively dead. This was an important change in marriage. 
 
 It is true, I think, that significant changes in major institutions like marriage need to be debated and considered very carefully. We are having that debate and that careful consideration of including same-sex couples within the institution of marriage right now. 
 
 The laws that ban, or that fail to recognize, same-sex marriages do discriminate. They discriminate against individuals who happen to be gay. Now, some forms of discrimination make reasonable sense, and states sometimes discriminate toward a good purpose. One example is the ban in all states on children getting married. The state has a legitimate interest in protecting children, and setting an age requirement for marriage is a form of protection for children. But children are not barred from marrying forever; they grow up. 
 
 There is no rational reason to bar same-sex couples from marrying legally, and there are strong social reasons for states to recognize such marriages. Marriage between couples, whatever the sex of the parties, provides legal protections for the two spouses and for children that they are raising. Same-sex spouses and their children need these legal protections no less than opposite-sex spouses do. 
 
 Marriage makes the spouses legal family. Same-sex marriage is not like a man marrying his father or mother or a woman marrying her father or mother. A child and a parent are already legal family. People can certainly debate whether laws barring marriages between family members should be legal or not, but this would need to be debated on its own terms, separately from same-sex marriage, because the issues are different. One question that people have raised is whether first-cousin marriages should be legal. Such marriages are legal in some states but not in other states. The issue of whether first cousins should have the legal right to marry each other needs to be debated on its own merits. People need to ask what are the reasons why first cousins are barred from marrying in many states and whether those reasons serve a legitimate state interest. 
 
 The argument that the laws should recognize same-sex marriages does not mean that all marriages in every form should be recognized. People need to debate whether first-cousin marriages should be legal and why or why not. People need to debate whether polygamous marriages should be legal and why or why not. People have debated whether inter-racial marriages should be legal and why or why not. We are currently debating whether same-sex marriages should be legal and why or why not.
